CSSG.toolkit 0.1.2
  • Reference

    Select Marker Genes for Naming Cell Clusters

    naming_genes_selection.Rd

    Identifies representative marker genes for cell cluster naming by considering statistical significance, gene occurrence, and removal of undesired gene classes (mitochondrial/ribosomal).

    naming_genes_selection(
  sc_project,
  type = "primary",
  top_n = 25,
  p_val = 0.05,
  select_stat = "p_val",
  mito_content = FALSE,
  ribo_content = FALSE,
  extend_missing = TRUE
)

    Arguments

    sc_project

    A single-cell project object containing marker gene metadata.

    type

    A character string specifying the marker category to use. Must be one of: 'subtypes', 'subclasses', 'cluster', or 'primary' (default).

    top_n

    A numeric value specifying the maximum number of marker genes to retain per cluster. Default is 25.

    p_val

    A numeric value specifying the p-value threshold for marker selection. Default is 0.05.

    select_stat

    A character string specifying the statistic used to rank genes. Options: 'p_val' (default) or 'avg_logFC'.

    mito_content

    A logical value indicating whether to include mitochondrial genes. Default is FALSE.

    ribo_content

    A logical value indicating whether to include ribosomal genes. Default is FALSE.

    extend_missing

    A logical value indicating whether to add non-significant genes as names when none are found. If TRUE and no such genes are available, the top 5 genes by effect size will be added. Default is TRUE.

    Value

    An updated `sc_project` object with selected naming marker genes stored in the `metadata$naming_markers` slot.

    Details

    The function performs the following steps: - Validates the `type` parameter and selects appropriate marker metadata. - Filters genes based on p-value. - Optionally removes mitochondrial and ribosomal genes. - Ranks genes by cluster based on occurrence, p-value, and log fold change. - Selects the top `top_n` genes per cluster. - Removes duplicated genes across clusters to improve naming specificity. - Ensures each cluster retains at least two marker genes.

    Examples

    sc_project <- naming_genes_selection(sc_project,
  type = "primary",
  top_n = 25,
  p_val = 0.05,
  mito_content = FALSE,
  ribo_content = FALSE,
  extend_missing = TRUE
)
#> Error: object 'sc_project' not found
